metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of flux observation matrix (eddy covariance system of Upper Daman Superstation) of the MUlti-Scale Observation EXperiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces 2012 (MUSOEXE-12)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the Daman superstation eddy covariance system (EC) at the highest layer in the flux observation matrix from 30 May to 15 September, 2012. The site (100.37223° E, 38.85551° N) was located in a cropland (maize surface) in Daman irrigation district, which is near Zhangye, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1556.06 m. The EC was installed at a height of 34 m; the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (CSAT3&Li7500A) was 0.17 m.
Raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Edire post-processing software (University of Edinburgh, http://www.geos.ed.ac.uk/abs/research/micromet/EdiRe/), including spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. Moreover, the observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC), which was proposed by Foken and Wichura [1996]: class 1 (level 0: Δst<30 and ITC<30), class 2 (level 1: Δst<100 and ITC<100), and class 3 (level 2: Δst>100 and ITC>100), representing high-, medium-, and low-quality data, respectively. In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 3% of the 30 min raw record; and (4) data were rejected at night when the friction velocity (u*) was less than 0.1 m/s. There were 48 records per day; the missing data were replaced with -6999. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m^3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m^3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m^2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m^2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m^2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xlsx format.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2016) (for multi-scale observation experiment or sites information), Xu et al. (2013) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to estimate evapotranspiration in heterogeneous land surfaces?
Example.Answer: A data collection method used to estimate evapotranspiration in heterogeneous land surfaces involves using a two-source energy balance (TSEB) model with soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera. This method includes field observations from a boundary layer tower, measuring meteorological parameters and turbulent fluxes, and capturing thermal images to partition evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration using the Craig–Gordon model.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in collecting multiscale observation data for eco-hydrological processes?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge in collecting multiscale observation data for eco-hydrological processes is the poor availability of such observations, which hinders progress in upscaling these processes on heterogeneous surfaces. To address this challenge, a hierarchically nested instrumentation system was used during the HiWATER experiment to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that captures eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset that captures eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is the multiscale dataset obtained from the HiWATER experiment in an oasis-desert area. This dataset is composed of flux observation matrices, eco-hydrological sensor networks, hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing, and synchronical ground measurements, with data available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'multi-scale observation experiment' in eco-hydrological research?
Definition.Answer: A multi-scale observation experiment in eco-hydrological research refers to the collection of data at various spatial and temporal scales to capture the complex interactions of water, energy, and ecological processes across different landscapes. This involves using hierarchically nested observation systems, including eddy covariance towers, remote sensing technologies, and ground-based measurements, to comprehensively study processes like evapotranspiration across diverse environments.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods using eddy covariance systems compare to those employing high-resolution thermal cameras in terms of capturing evapotranspiration dynamics over heterogeneous surfaces?
Comparison.Answer: The eddy covariance systems provide continuous measurements of turbulent fluxes such as heat and moisture at a high temporal resolution, which is crucial for understanding surface energy exchanges. In contrast, high-resolution thermal cameras capture soil and canopy component temperatures, which are then used to estimate evapotranspiration. The thermal camera approach allows for the separation of soil and vegetation components in estimating surface fluxes, which can be critical in heterogeneous areas but requires sophisticated image classification to ensure accuracy.

Comparison.Question: How does the application of a two-source energy balance model compare to a one-source model in terms of estimating surface evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes?
Comparison.Answer: The two-source energy balance model differentiates between soil and canopy components, allowing for more accurate estimation of surface evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes where soil and vegetation temperatures and resistances differ. This contrasts with a one-source model that treats the surface as a homogeneous entity, which can lead to inaccuracies in heterogeneous conditions. The two-source model, although more complex and requiring more detailed input data, provides improved estimates by addressing the distinct energy partitioning between soil and canopy.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways do errors in image classification impact the estimation of component temperatures in eco-hydrological studies?
Interpretation.Answer: Errors in image classification can significantly impact the estimation of component temperatures by misclassifying soil and vegetation pixels, leading to incorrect temperature readings. These classification errors can vary with vegetation abundance, causing an overestimation of canopy temperature under high vegetation density. Such inaccuracies can propagate through models like the TSEB, affecting the estimation of surface fluxes, especially in regions with strong advective conditions. Correct classification is essential for accurate component temperature separation and subsequent energy balance calculations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the complexity in the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model, and how does it affect the accurate estimation of evapotranspiration over heterogeneous landscapes?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The complexity in the TSEB model arises from over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated, and the requirement for parameters and observations that are not readily available from operational satellite- and ground-based data. This complexity affects the accurate estimation of evapotranspiration as it limits the range of applications of the model, especially in heterogeneous landscapes with mixed soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the primary causes of errors in estimating component temperatures for evapotranspiration models using remote sensing data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Errors in estimating component temperatures are primarily caused by image classification errors, which vary with vegetation abundance. Additionally, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance and uncertainties in the estimated temperatures due to the classification errors can lead to inaccuracies. These errors result in an overestimation of canopy temperature under developing vegetation abundance and contribute to the uncertainty in the TSEB model's performance.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the availability of multiscale observations a challenge in upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The availability of multiscale observations is a challenge because of the inherent complexity in capturing eco-hydrological processes across different spatial scales. This complexity requires hierarchically nested instrumentation and a sparse network to investigate interactions within diverse landscapes, such as oasis-desert systems. Without these comprehensive observations, it is difficult to accurately model and understand eco-hydrological processes across heterogeneous surfaces.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of implementing a multiscale observation system on the quality and scope of eco-hydrological data collected in heterogeneous landscapes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing a multiscale observation system, such as that used in the HiWATER experiment, leads to enhanced quality and scope of eco-hydrological data. It captures multi-scale processes by utilizing a hierarchically nested instrumentation setup, including eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations. The integration of hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing and synchronical ground measurements further enriches the dataset, making it possible to address challenges like upscaling eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous surfaces effectively.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of classification errors in thermal imagery on the component temperature measurements used in energy balance models?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Classification errors in thermal imagery can lead to significant inaccuracies in component temperature measurements, which can adversely affect energy balance models like the TSEB. Misclassifying soil as vegetation pixels can result in overestimations of canopy temperature, particularly in areas with developing vegetation abundance. This misrepresentation can introduce biases in the estimation of sensible and latent heat fluxes, thereby affecting the overall accuracy of evapotranspiration estimates. Additionally, ignoring atmospheric radiation effects could compound these uncertainties.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of collecting multi-scale observational data in eco-hydrological research, particularly in heterogeneous landscapes?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives of collecting multi-scale observational data in eco-hydrological research, especially in heterogeneous landscapes, are to address the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes and to provide a comprehensive dataset through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales. This allows for the capture of multi-scale and multidisciplinary data, which is crucial for understanding the interactions and processes within complex ecosystems like oasis-desert systems.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to use ground-based measurements, such as eddy covariance systems, in conjunction with satellite and airborne remote sensing for estimating evapotranspiration?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important to use ground-based measurements such as eddy covariance systems along with satellite and airborne remote sensing for estimating evapotranspiration because these methods complement each other in measuring surface fluxes. Ground-based measurements provide high temporal resolution and accuracy, while remote sensing offers broader spatial coverage. Together, they enhance the reliability of evapotranspiration estimates, especially in heterogeneous and strongly advective environments.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in processing eddy covariance data to ensure quality and accuracy in flux observations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The processing of eddy covariance data involves several steps to ensure quality and accuracy: outlier removal, time delay correction, coordinate rotation (second rotation), frequency response correction, sonic virtual temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction. Quality evaluation focuses on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics. Data filtering includes removing erroneous data, excluding data around precipitation events, eliminating data with a high missing rate, and discarding weak turbulence data during nighttime.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are multiscale observations implemented and managed to study eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous landscapes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Multiscale observations are managed through a hierarchically nested instrumentation setup, including a sparse network for oasis-desert interactions and a superstation in the oasis. This system comprises eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and an eco-hydrological sensor network. Airborne remote sensing missions further support these observations with LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and L-band microwave radiometers, ensuring comprehensive data collection across scales.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What data collection methods are employed to separate and validate soil and canopy component temperatures in a strongly advective agricultural area?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Data collection for separating and validating soil and canopy component temperatures involves using a high-resolution thermal camera to capture thermal radiation images, which are then classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. The thermal infrared temperatures are converted to radiation temperatures using observed long-wave radiation and emissivities. These measurements are validated against radiometric temperatures calculated from incoming long-wave radiation, ensuring accurate separation of component temperatures.

Enablement.Question: What conditions and technologies enable the accurate partitioning of evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration over heterogeneous land surfaces?
Enablement.Answer: The use of soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera, along with the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and eddy covariance measurements, enables accurate partitioning of evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration over heterogeneous land surfaces.

Expectation.Question: Why might multiscale observation data be poorly available in eco-hydrological research, and what expectations could be set for improving this availability?
Expectation.Answer: Progress in upscaling eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations, as noted in the context of HiWATER. The expectation for improving this availability involves designing experiments with instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.

Expectation.Question: What expectations could be set for the separation of evaporation and transpiration in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area using a dataset from a high-precision thermal infrared camera?
Expectation.Answer: The expectation is that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied effectively even in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas. This method allows for the successful separation of soil and vegetation latent fluxes with reasonable accuracy, as demonstrated by reliable estimations of E/ET% and T/ET% values.

Expectation.Question: What are the anticipated challenges in accurately estimating surface fluxes in irrigated agricultural areas, and how can a dataset address these challenges?
Expectation.Answer: Accurate estimation of surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas is challenging due to incomplete energy balance closure and errors in surface–air temperature differences. A dataset addressing these challenges would involve robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculations, which are crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. The TSEB model, using data from thermal infrared cameras and ground-based measurements, is expected to provide reliable estimates despite these challenges.

Judgmental.Question: What is your assessment of the challenges faced in collecting multiscale observational data for eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems?
Judgmental.Answer: The main challenge in collecting multiscale observational data for eco-hydrological processes is the availability of such observations across hierarchical scales. This requires a comprehensive approach involving a sparse network of instruments like EC towers and AMSs, as well as advanced remote sensing technologies. Despite these efforts, accurately capturing multiscale interactions remains a considerable challenge due to the complexity and heterogeneity of the landscape.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the implications of the data processing techniques used for eddy covariance measurements on the quality of flux data in agricultural research?
Judgmental.Answer: The data processing techniques for eddy covariance measurements, such as coordinate rotation and frequency response correction, significantly impact the quality of flux data. These techniques address various potential errors and biases, thus improving the reliability of the data. The quality assessment and filtering steps, including removing erroneous and low-turbulence data, ensure that only high-quality data contribute to agricultural research, enhancing the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges associated with using the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model for estimating evapotranspiration in strongly advective environments.
Request/Directive.Answer: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model faces challenges in strongly advective environments due to the complexity of accurately calculating multiple resistances and the need for specific parameters and observations. The uncertainty in surface-air temperature differences, particularly in determining surface soil and vegetation component temperatures, can lead to errors in the model's performance. Additionally, image classification errors related to vegetation abundance can affect the accuracy of component temperature separation, impacting the reliability of evapotranspiration estimations.
